docs.lead_paragraph: One day in December, Walter Davis of the Phoenix Suns scores 43 points, a career high, and the following day comes forth and volunteers that he has a drug problem, and is sent to a rehabilitation center for six weeks. One day in January, the New England Patriots lose a game to the Chicago Bears, 46-10, while half a nation watches, and the following day the coach comes forth and says that several players on the team have had drug problems. In each case, the observer wonders what significance, if any, drugs had on performance. We wonder, what are we watching? This is a major problem for the businesses that are sports.

docs.lead_paragraph: NOT long ago, Marie Sciallo of Huntington Station could only drive with one hand on the steering wheel of her car. She needed her other hand to hold her head straight. Mrs. Sciallo has a disorder that caused her neck muscles to contract involuntarily, and drug therapy had not been successful in controlling it. A year ago, 60-year-old Irving Feder of Bayside was still barely able to move his right hand despite months of intensive physical therapy following a stroke. ''I didn't think I'd ever be able to get dressed or feed myself again,'' he said.

docs.lead_paragraph: In what has become an annual phenomenon, older New Yorkers are resuming their campaign for a state program to subsidize prescription drugs for the elderly. Even before lawmakers convened here this month, Governor Cuomo had received 60,000 postcards in a mass appeal for action on the matter. The mail campaign was organized by the New York Statewide Senior Action Council, a lobbying organization. Groups across the state are planning a demonstration here Feb. 18 and smaller delegations are scheduled to visit Albany each week until the session ends.

headline.main: THE AGED PUSH ALBANY ON PRESCRIPTION SUBSIDY

byline.original: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: G.D. Searle & Company announced yesterday that, because of what it termed unwarranted lawsuits, it was discontinuing the sale of its two intrauterine contraceptive devices in the United States. About a million American women use Searle's Copper-7, the most frequently prescribed IUD, or its Tatum-T. Searle was the last major manufacturer of intrauterine devices in the United States to hold out against increasing costs of product-liability litigation and insurance. With the company's withdrawal, this type of birth control device will no longer be available in this country.

headline.main: SEARLE, ASSAILING LAWSUITS, HALTS U.S. SALES OF INTRAUTERINE DEVICES
